December 2025

By the time you receive this edition of the Brenham Banner-Press, I hope you’ll still have time to grab a couple of chairs and head downtown for our annual Lighted Christmas Parade. This year’s theme, “A Very Vintage Christmas,” promises all the nostalgic charm of the season. Festivities began Friday with First Friday Farmers Market, the Jingle Bell Market at Ant Street Inn, and Cold Nights Holiday Tunes. Saturday’s activities start at 5:30 p.m. on the steps of the Brenham Heritage Museum, where carolers and local Girl Scouts—including my granddaughters' troop—will fill the evening with Christmas music. The parade begins promptly at 6:00 p.m., featuring more than one hundred entries and a night of community spirit and family fun. Afterward, children are invited to “Sit with Santa” in Alamo Alley.

At last week’s City Council meeting, we had the privilege of recognizing our Development Services Department for receiving a top award from the Texas Chapter of the American Planning Association. This honor highlights our city’s ongoing commitment to balancing Brenham’s historic charm with thoughtful, forward-looking growth. Congratulations to Stephanie Doland, Shauna Laauwe, Kim Hodde, Allen Jacobs, Sarah Hill, David Doelitsch, Mark Pierce, David Moore, and Don Clark for their outstanding work.

Also, at our meeting, we recognized the Brenham Animal Shelter for receiving Best Friends Animal Society's No-Kill Shelter designation. The no-kill shelter recognition represents leadership, integrity, innovation, and transformation of our shelter operations. Last fiscal year, Animal Services Manager Megan Gray and her staff cared for 791 animals and facilitated adoptions for 783 of them, resulting in a 94.8% save rate. Which is amazing!! Congratulations to Megan and her staff for this outstanding achievement. I would also like to give a special thanks to our in-house veterinarian, Dr. Charles Mohr, for his hard work and unwavering dedication to the health and well-being of every animal.

Recently, members of the City Council and administrative staff were invited to Valmont Industries for lunch and a brief tour hosted by Senior Plant Manager Manish Dhaigude. The visit was both informative and impressive. Valmont’s Brenham facility manufactures a wide range of poles for lighting and other applications, ranging from just a few inches to several feet in diameter. These structures are shipped throughout the southern United States. They currently employ more than 350 individuals and are actively hiring to meet growing demand. Remarkably, more than 100 employees commute over 70 miles each way to work in Brenham. It is our hope—as well as Manish’s—that these hardworking individuals and their families will soon find opportunities to call Brenham home.

I was also invited by Shawn Koonce, Executive Director of the Boys & Girls Club of Washington County, to tour their facility and learn more about their mission. The City of Brenham is proud to partner with the club by providing the building, programming support, and helping with certain costs, such as utilities and insurance. The heart of the operation, however, comes from community support. The club serves more than 155 young people, ages 5–18, providing a safe, encouraging environment where youth can grow into responsible, productive, and caring citizens.

The Boys & Girls Club operates entirely on donations, and no gift is too small to make a difference. If you feel led to contribute, please visit their website—Boys and Girls Club of Washington County at https://www.bgc-brenham.org/ — or drop off a donation directly at the club. Shawn and his team, as well as the children they serve, will be deeply grateful. Be sure to check out all the fun holiday events by visiting www.cityofbrenham.org

As always, thank you for your continued support of our community. Feel free to email me with questions at info@cityofbrenham.org .

Mayor Kenjura

Mayor Kenjura

November with Councilmember Dr. Paul LaRoche

Hello Brenham! As the holiday season approaches, November gives us a special reason to slow down and remember all the things we’re thankful for. Here in Brenham, that list is long — from our strong sense of community to the dedicated city staff and the families who make this town such a special place to call home. Thanksgiving reminds us to slow down, gather around the table, and appreciate the people and the progress around us.

Construction on our new Brenham Fire Station continues to make progress. The structural steel is now 95% complete, and the CMU walls (cinder block) are 99% finished. Roof decking is also well underway, sitting at about 90% complete. Looking ahead, crews are beginning the exterior wall construction, which will be followed by ductwork installation and interior wall framing in the coming weeks. Completion is still on schedule for April 2026, and we are excited to see the progress.

Work also continues on Brenham’s Jasper and Catahoula water wells. Testing for both wells has been completed, and Rockfish, our hydrologist, is reviewing the data. We expect to receive their report by the end of the week.

Once the analysis is complete, Strand Engineering will begin a blending study to determine the best treatment process for our water system. After that, they’ll present a proposal for the City to move forward with the design of a Jasper Aquifer well and onsite treatment facility.

K9 Project – Brenham Police Department

Thanks to the incredible generosity of our community, the Brenham Police Department’s K9 Unit is now officially in service! Sergeant Jimmy Ha and his K9 partner, Maki, have completed their training and certifications and are already on patrol, serving as a vital part of our public safety team.

A special thank-you goes to the City’s Maintenance Department for preparing and outfitting the new K9 vehicle, ensuring Maki and Sergeant Ha have the tools they need to serve safely and effectively. This program was made possible through community donations, and I know the continued support is always welcome.

- Friday, November 7th, 2025, from 3:00pm - 6:00pm. Join us on the first Friday of each month for the Brenham Farmer & Artisan Market, which features fresh, local foods and products in the heart of Downtown Brenham.

- Shop and sip on Saturday, November 29th, 2025, 11:00am - 4:00pm. Downtown Brenham is hosting its third annual Cocoa Crawl in conjunction with Small Business Saturday. Join us on November 29 from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. to shop and sip!

- Friday, December 5th, 2025, 7:00pm - 10:00pm. Get ready for a night of music, dancing, and holiday cheer with the band, Night Moves.

Christmas Stroll in Downtown Brenham - Saturday, December 6th, 2025, 6:00pm - 10:00pm. There will be many fun activities, including Breakfast with Santa, live music and dance performances, caroling, and much more. The annual Lighted Parade is Saturday at 6:00pm.

Fall is here, and the weather has finally cooled off, giving us all a break from the long Texas summer. Whether you’re enjoying a football game, a family dinner, or a quiet walk through town, I hope this season brings you and your family happiness and a safe holiday season. From my family to yours and on behalf of the Mayor and City Council, Happy Thanksgiving!

Councilmember LaRoche

October 2025

It's been a busy few weeks in the city, with annexation being the topic that generated a lot of interest among the citizens of our community. Much of the concern centered around the proposed development of multi-family(apartments) units in Phase 1 of the annexed property. At the Planning & Zoning board meeting, a large crowd of citizens filled the room to voice their opposition to building multi-family units. Because of their concerns, the developer of Stylecraft Homes agreed to withdraw their plans for such units and replace them with townhomes and twin homes. As Mayor Pro Tem Clint Kolby noted at our last council meeting, a respectful and civil debate between the public and the City led to a compromise that benefits everyone involved. I also shared that while growth is inevitable, we must plan and communicate in ways that preserve our small-town charm and the unique qualities that make our community such a desirable place to live.

This past Tuesday, we opened the bids for the expansion of the water treatment plant located on S. Austin St. The initial low bid of $27 million was submitted and is under review by staff and Strand engineers. This project will be the largest contract ever issued by the City of Brenham in its history. This stresses the importance of water and how it has become one of our most valuable natural resources, replacing oil. As the saying goes, "you can live without oil, but you cannot live without water”.

We await test results for drilling deep water wells behind the Senior Center. Test results should be available in the coming weeks. Once complete, these wells will supplement our supply from Lake Somerville and, more importantly, provide a backup water source for the City. Currently, Brenham relies on a single line for water. If that line were disrupted, the City would be without water until repairs were made—an outcome we must work to prevent. This is why careful planning and development are so critical for both current and future generations.

Water is becoming one of the most urgent issues in Texas and is expected to be the top topic in the next legislative session, especially regarding the “rule of capture.” This 1901 law, originally written for oil and gas but also applying to water, allows landowners to pump and sell whatever lies beneath their land. As a result, investors are buying property, drilling wells, and building pipelines to send water to urban areas. Given Brenham’s proximity to Harris County—only 60 miles away—our community is in a vulnerable position.

I am told that the end is in sight, and hopefully, with weather permitting, the water lines and resurfacing of the streets will be completed in the next few months. Thanks to everyone in that neighborhood for being patient.

This needed improvements, and once again, thanks to BCDC for funding this historical neighborhood park. Now that our unbearable Texas summer temperatures are beginning to drop and cooler days are around the corner, take the time to have a stroll through one of our many beautiful parks.

Happy October, Brenham! Be sure to check out all the fun fall events by visiting www.cityofbrenham.org

Mayor Kenjura

September with Councilmember Steve Soman

On August 2, 2025, 19 volunteers from three Brenham congregations joined forces to assist Trinity Church in Center Point, Texas. Flood relief supplies had overwhelmed the church’s sanctuary, preventing worship services. In a remarkable display of teamwork, the group relocated the supplies to a nearby warehouse in just three hours. Their work enabled Trinity Church to resume services the very next day, restoring a sacred space for the community. This effort highlights the strength of unity among Brenham’s faith communities in times of crisis.

Following a devastating July 4th rainstorm in San Angelo, Thielemann Construction Company, in partnership with Champion Fellowship, spearheaded a home restoration project for a single mother whose house sustained severe flood damage. Over 3½ days, a dedicated team of nine volunteers transformed the home, installing new sheetrock, doors, flooring, cabinets, plumbing, appliances, beds, and furnishings. This comprehensive effort allowed the family to return home after more than five weeks of displacement, offering them not just a house but renewed hope and stability.

  • Evans Cabinet and Door, LTD (Brenham)

The flood relief projects were supported by those who traveled and worked on-site and countless others who offered prayers, financial contributions, and encouragement. The city of Brenham extends heartfelt gratitude to everyone involved, emphasizing that every act of support played a vital role in these successes.

These flood relief initiatives reflect the heart of Brenham’s community—churches and businesses coming together to serve and, in this case, extending this effort beyond the city limits. By extending a hand to those in Center Point and San Angelo, they have demonstrated the transformative power of unity, generosity, and faith in action. This is a call to all of us to continue supporting one another, showcasing the spirit and character of Washington County and Brenham communities.

Thank you and I look forward to seeing you around town this fall at all the fun events.

Councilmember Steve Soman

August 2025

It’s been a busy summer in Brenham, and I’m excited to share a few updates. We finished out another amazing July with Hot Nights Cool Tunes. This past weekend had one of the largest crowds I have witnessed over the years at this event. Parking extended for several blocks in every direction from downtown. Again, thanks to everyone who had a part in this, as it has grown in popularity each year. Also, many thanks to our sponsors who make it possible for the bands to perform and for everyone to enjoy this free event.  I hope you could make it at least one weekend to enjoy the festivities. It’s always a great time. Summer break is coming to an end, and school will be starting in just a few weeks. It’s been a quick yet eventful summer, and I hope you and your family have enjoyed every minute of it.

As you know, we are working to bring back a trained K-9 officer. They are such an asset in helping track missing persons, detect illegal drugs, assist during high-risk calls, and protect our officers and the community. Since ending the program in September 2020, law enforcement in Washington County has requested a K-9 more than 150 times.

  • Checks accepted made out to the City of Brenham (memo k9 program)

If you have any questions about the program or the donations, Sergeant Jimmy Ha will be happy to help. He can be reached at (979) 530-2488.

The City of Brenham and Solid Bridge Construction have successfully completed six of the seven drainage improvement projects funded by a $5.1 million grant from the Texas General Land Office. The final project—replacing the well-known low-water crossing on Burleson Street—will begin in August. A new bridge will allow stormwater to flow underneath, eliminating the need to close the road during heavy rainfall. Burleson Street will be closed to through traffic during construction, which is expected to be completed by February 2026.

  • Tom Dee Storm Sewer Upgrades

The Street Department has been hard at work this summer, making much-needed improvements to our city streets. Crews are currently paving Church Street and Mansfield Street. After that, they’ll reconstruct and pave Dark Street. To close out the year, work will begin on Heritage Drive, Carriage Lane, and Century Circle.

Did you know the pavement alone for Church and Mansfield Streets costs $95,000? Street work is expensive, but we’re proud to be extending the life of these roads for another 20–30 years. Looking ahead to 2026, we plan to repave and improve approximately 15 to 20 more streets across town.

GAC is wrapping up boring work for Phase 2 in the Tom Green and Perkins Street areas. Nextlink will move to Phase 3 starting Tuesday, July 22, 2025, beginning on Gun and Rod Road. Staff continues to monitor GAC’s work, maintaining communication with residents as needed. GAC is following safety protocols around existing utilities, replacing soil and grass, and repairing any damage to your property.

In the last week, there has been a lot of publicity regarding issues with our current post office. For the past twenty-plus years, the need for a new facility or a new location has fallen on deaf ears. It was only after Amazon delivered over 11,000 packages to our outdated facility, which delayed or halted regular mail delivery, that we finally got the attention of the USPS. Rep McCaul’s office is experiencing much of the frustration that we locally have been dealing with over the years, but hopefully has made a few inroads that can point us in the right direction. It’s critical that we do not lose the momentum currently taking place and that everyone continues to email and call his office regularly to express your concerns at mccaul.casework@mail.house.gov or call 979-431-6480.

Fire Department’s 56th Annual Fireman’s Fiesta – August 9–10

This is the Brenham Fire Department’s biggest fundraiser of the year, packed with food, games, and fun at the Fireman’s Training Center. Come Saturday for the Cornhole Tournament or Sunday for all you can eat. There are lots of fun activities for the family. Hope to see you there!

Stay cool and enjoy the last few weeks of summer break before school resumes next month. As always, thank you for your continued support in making Brenham such a great place to be. Feel free to send questions to me at info@cityofbrenham.org .

Mayor Kenjura

Mayor Kenjura

June 2025

Over the past few weeks, the City Utility Department and I have received numerous calls about the installation of fiber optic lines by Nextlink. Understandably, this project has raised concerns among residents. It’s important to remember that the city maintains a utility easement extending 10 to 15 feet from the curb onto your property. This area has essential infrastructure—water, gas, sewer, broadband, and more. While we recognize that the ongoing work may cause temporary disruptions and some damage, Nextlink is aware that any damage done by their staff in installing the fiber network throughout town is their responsibility to return the property and utilities to their original state before construction started. City staff are actively engaged in this process and meet weekly with Nextlink’s contractors to address concerns and monitor progress. On a side note, the State of Texas recognizes fiber companies like Nextlink and AT&T as public utilities. They are permitted to install their services within the city’s right-of-way, provided they meet all permitting requirements—which both companies have. It’s possible that Comcast may also pursue service installation, though the number of viable providers will ultimately depend on subscriber demand and market feasibility.

The TxDOT project at the intersection of Park Street and Academy is nearing completion. While the pedestrian improvements are appreciated, I share your frustration that the project did not address much-needed left-turn lanes on Academy and MLK. As traffic increases in this area, the lack of turn lanes will likely cause growing congestion. With a bit more planning and engineering by TxDOT, this intersection could have been made more efficient for both motorists and pedestrians.

Housing remains a frequent topic of interest. Our Economic Development Director, Teresa Rosales, recently shared some insights from the first quarter of 2025:

: $299,000 (up 4.7% from last year)

We currently have 219 active listings, up 63% from the same time last year. The average days on the market have increased slightly to 95 days. Building permits are also up—82 in Q1 2025 compared to 75 in Q1 2024.

Finally, mark your calendars for these events happening right here at home this month!

The Annual Juneteenth Parade through Downtown Brenham will start at 10:30 a.m. on Saturday, June 14, followed by festivities at Fireman's Park. Find out more on the WCJA Facebook page.

These events are great way to kick off the summer and support our vibrant community.

Have a great June, and I look forward to sharing more updates next month. As always, feel free to send questions to me at info@cityofbrenham.org.

Mayor Kenjura

May 2025

Sent to Banner Press for the Sunday edition May 1, 2025 - By the time you’re reading this edition of the Mayor’s Minute, voting in our local elections will likely be over or nearing completion. This has undoubtedly been one of the most contentious and divisive elections in recent memory. While healthy debate and differing opinions are vital to democracy, this election cycle has seen a troubling increase in misinformation and inflammatory rhetoric. I hope that once the votes are counted and the winners announced, we can come together as a community and refocus on what truly matters—doing what’s best for Brenham and our schools. I’ve said it before: Brenham is a unique city, shaped by a rich history, deep roots, and dedicated citizens.

Our school system, founded in April 1875, was the first public school district in Texas. For 150 years, Brenham ISD has produced outstanding graduates and contributed greatly to our state. Last week, I received an email thanking city and school leaders for their service—and expressing concern that the negativity of this election might discourage future public servants from stepping forward. We must not let that happen.

The time to heal is now—not tomorrow, not next week. Let’s set aside our differences and work together to make Brenham an even better place to live, work, and learn.

I’m also proud to share that Governor Abbott recently recognized Brenham as a Film Friendly Texas Certified Community. As I noted in our press release, this distinction highlights our city’s charm, heritage, and hospitality—while creating new economic opportunities. This follows our recent designation as a Tourism Friendly Certified Community, another great milestone. Tourism now brings an estimated $120 million annually to Brenham and Washington County. Special thanks to Jennifer Eckermann and the entire team who worked tirelessly to earn these certifications. Their efforts help showcase what we already know: Brenham is a place worth visiting—and an even better place to call home.

Thank you to everyone who contributes to making Brenham the vibrant, welcoming, and forward-looking community it is today.

Got questions? Just shoot me an email at info@cityofbrenham.org —I’d love to hear from you!

Mayor Kenjura

March 2025

As Mayor, I am pleased to announce that work has begun on two major projects approved by the current City Council over the past few months. These projects represent significant investments, and the decision to move forward was not taken lightly, as we are committed to responsibly managing your taxpayer dollars.

On November 20, 2024, the City of Brenham and BRW Architects opened proposals for the construction of Brenham Fire Station No. 2. Nine proposals were received, ranging from $6,218,005.00 to $7,123,625.00. The bid was awarded to Collier Construction Company on February 6, 2025, with their bid of $6,218,005.00. Collier has completed other projects for the City, such as the modernization of the Nancy Carol Roberts Memorial Library, the Brenham Pet Adoption and Animal Care Facility, and most recently, the Crossover Nature Trail at Hohlt Park. We look forward to getting this project started.

To meet the growing needs of our community, the city has begun drilling a new groundwater well at the Loesch Street location. This well will reach approximately 800 feet deep, with a second well planned for the same location at a depth of 1,100–1,200 feet. These wells will tap into two aquifers—the Jasper and the Catahoula — and together, they are expected to produce over 1 million gallons of water per day.

Brenham is proud to have one of the best public park systems in Texas for cities with populations under 30,000. In keeping with this tradition, bids were recently opened for improvements to Jackson Street Park. We received eight competitive bids, ranging from $1.145 million to $1.35 million.

Economic Development Director Teresa Rosales recently attended a housing conference at Texas A&M covering our five-county area (Austin, Colorado, Fayette, Lee, and Washington Counties).

    • o 2023: 5.2 months
    • o 2024: 6.9 months

Interest rates have significantly influenced the housing market over the past three years. Experts predict a rate drop of 0.5% to 1% by the end of this year—let’s hope they’re right!

Mayor Kenjura

February 2025

Happy February! It's hard to believe January 2025 has come and gone. The new year always brings a lot of anticipation and excitement, and this one was no exception for Brenham.

Smithsonian Exhibit – Simon Exhibit – Camptown Exhibit – Freedom Colonies of Washington County Exhibit – Hasskarl Auditorium at the Simon Theatre Reenactment

First, I want to thank Jennifer Eckermann and her fantastic team for their outstanding work and for putting the Smithsonian Exhibit together to benefit our citizens and the many visitors who came to our city.

Interested in more local history? I want to remind everyone that there are two permanent exhibits available for viewing anytime: the Camptown Exhibit located at Jerry Wilson Park (Alamo and Chappell Hill St) and the Freedom Colonies of Washington County Exhibit in Belle's Alley, which can be entered through Toubin Park. Both exhibits depict our black community's integral part and significant contributions to Brenham’s history.

Speaking of history, the Hasskarl Auditorium at the Simon Theatre was packed on a recent Saturday afternoon for a reenactment of the speech Sam Houston gave on March 31, 1861, on the steps of the Washington County Courthouse. Brad Nies, professor of Theatre Arts at Blinn College, performed the speech reenactment. The famous address occurred after Houston was removed as Governor of Texas for refusing to swear allegiance to the Confederacy. A big thank you goes to Mr. Tom Stevens and the Washington County Historical Commission for hosting this event and for a truly informative event.

The City of Brenham has initiated a new pet program at the Brenham Animal Shelter to assist City pet owners with the costs of spaying and neutering their pets. The reduced fee for this program is $25, with the ultimate benefit of reducing the number of homeless animals in our community. For more information, don't hesitate to contact Megan Gray, Animal Services Manager, at mgray@cityofbrenham.org or call 979-337-7351.

At our regular City Council meeting, we voted to approve a contract with NextLink to begin installing Broadband within the city limits. The installation has a time frame of anywhere from 18 to 36 months, depending on how many work crews are assigned to this project by NextLink. Essentially, this will be the same process performed by other broadband providers (AT&T, Comcast, etc.), and the noises from the boring process along the side of streets can cause issues for property owners; however, we’ve worked hard to ensure the City’s Utility Department, led by William Bissett, has negotiated the necessary terms to ensure properties are restored to their original or better condition once the work is complete.

Also, at the last City Council meeting, we approved sending out bids for Phase I of the Brenham Family Park donated to the city by Ed and Evellyn Kruse. This has been a very slow process due to getting approval from the Texas Parks and Wildlife Agency. But we are excited to get started!

The city received a grant from Parks and Wildlife for $750,000 to be used for the design and implementation of the amenities in the park. The comprehensive plan developed by Quiddity Engineering was submitted in 2019 and was just approved in late 2024. Along with the grant BCDC (Brenham Community Development Corp) has given the city, through revenue raised by the sales tax portion designated for parks and recreation, a total of $1,800,000. The total cost of Phase I is expected to exceed these amounts. The main feature of Phase I will be a 4-acre lake for fishing, kayaking, and/or paddle boating. Also included is a one-mile walking and biking trail paved alongside the lake.

Brenham Family Park – Naming Rights and Donation Opportunity

For more information, contact Dane Rau, Director of Public Works, Kyle Branham, Public Works Project Manager, me, or any City Council member. Your support will help make this vision a reality.

January 2025

I hope everyone had a wonderful Christmas, and I’m wishing you all a healthy and happy New Year! In my last "Mayor's Minute," I discussed some key priorities from the 2020 master plan, Historic Past – Bold Future 2040 including:

The City of Brenham continues to invest in our historic downtown area, led by the Main Street Board under Leigh Linden's leadership and her board. Each month, various events are held that bring tourists to our community, contributing to our economy and helping fund the city’s budget. Mark your calendars for the annual Uptown Swirl on Saturday, January 18. This popular event features over 50 wines and champagnes available for sampling, while shopping at our local downtown merchants. The City will continue to invest the funds necessary to strengthen tourism and, at the same time, preserve and protect Brenham's historic past, making sure that our historic buildings are maintained and preserved.

Brenham and Washington County are fortunate to have a wide range of industries and businesses that provide diverse employment opportunities. Our Economic and Community Development Director, Theresa Rosales, has consistently identified new businesses and relocation opportunities. The Brenham Community Development Corporation (BCDC) also plays a key role in acquiring land and utility easements for new and existing businesses.

Our local businesses, both new and established, continue to provide valuable goods and services to our citizens and visitors, helping drive our economy. As Brenham grows, we anticipate opening more retail establishments in our area. However, it's crucial that this growth remains orderly and well-managed to preserve our city's unique identity. Stephanie Doland, our Development Director, and her team are dedicated to ensuring that Brenham grows thoughtfully while also addressing the community's future needs.

As our city grows, traffic congestion has become a growing concern. Public Works Director Dane Rau and his team are actively monitoring the most problematic areas and have shared a list of priorities with the City Council. One of the biggest challenges we face is the increasing cost of roadwork and repairs, which has skyrocketed since the COVID-19 pandemic. However, we’ve made significant improvements over the past couple of years, including expanding Chappell Hill Road to three lanes from Market Street to the 290 Loop, as well as updates to MLK Street, Salem Road, and Old Chappell Hill Road. Additionally, any future major thoroughfares will be designed with a width of 41 feet, compared to the 31 feet used in the past. We’re hopeful that, with the support of TXDOT (Texas Department of Transportation), we can continue to monitor and improve the traffic issue for the future.

Before I close, I’d like to remind everyone to visit the Smithsonian Exhibit and the 100th Anniversary celebration of the Simon Theatre at Morris Hall. The exhibit will be open through January 19th, with hours Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturday, 10 a.m. to 2 p.m.; and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 2 p.m.

In my last "Mayors Minute," I was asked about a plan that was done in 2020 entitled " Historic Past—Bold Future 2040 ." This plan took several months to complete and is a comprehensive plan for the City of Brenham, with a great deal of input from leaders and citizens in our community regarding how our city will look in 2040. Population projections are always challenging because of so many extenuating factors that can increase or decrease in numbers. Fortunately for Brenham, we have seen a substantial increase in our population over the last five years. Projections from four different sources in 2020 projected our population would be 18,624 in 2030 and 19,980 in 2040. In a recent article in The Banner Press , Texas-Demographics.com listed Brenham's population as 19,621, which we were not to reach until 2040. Those numbers are not surprising for everyone who has lived here for some time.

The top two priorities in the 2040 plan were our infrastructure (utility) and safety issues for the future. Number one was water, and I am pleased that the city council has already taken steps to secure an adequate supply of water for decades to come by issuing bonds to begin the drilling of several underground water wells at a depth that will produce the needed gallons of water along with the surface water from Lake Somerville for our projected growth in the future.

Along with the new wells, plans are being drawn for an extensive upgrade to our water treatment facility to maintain the quality of water we have enjoyed over the years. Another improvement is the planned improvement to our wastewater plant and the evaluation and replacement of several wastewater lift stations throughout the City, which will help prepare for our city's future growth.

Number two was safety. Our police and fire departments are always on the top of the list when it comes to budgeting and setting our top priorities for each year. Both departments have done an outstanding job, and I am pleased to announce that we have just opened bids on our new fire station, which is scheduled to be completed by the end of 2025. There were nine highly competitive bids, and we hope to award the contract in the next few weeks. A second fire station and the addition of new firefighters will be a true asset to our City in the coming years. In my next Mayor’s Minute in January, I will discuss more details of this plan for the future.

August 2024

July in Brenham has been a whirlwind of activity. Summer brings a flurry of tourism and special events, including Hot Nights Cool Tunes, First Friday Market Day, and our Fourth of July celebrations. This month also presented some challenges from Hurricane Beryl but we were blessed to only receive mild to moderate damage to our city and county.

The summer months also mark our annual budget planning. The budget for the fiscal year starting October 1, 2024, through September 30, 2025, was meticulously reviewed during our work session on July 22nd. We are pleased to present a balanced budget, thanks to a thorough assessment of various economic factors, including the presidential election outlook, unemployment rates, interest rates, inflation, and population growth.

The presidential race remains competitive, while the unemployment rate has held steady at 3.4%. The Federal Reserve's potential interest rate cuts could impact economic growth, particularly in home and business construction. Inflation has eased and is projected to stay around 3 to 3.5% in the coming year. Texas continues to be a business-friendly state with a robust workforce. Our city, located in the Texas Triangle (Dallas, Houston, Austin), benefits from the growth of the retail, industrial, educational, and healthcare sectors, which aligns with the overall population increase.

Our proposed General Fund 101 budget for the upcoming year is $24,415,757 in revenue/other financing services and $24,415,757 in expenditures, resulting in a balanced budget. Sales tax remains our top revenue source at $8,133,696, followed by property tax at $6,276,310. On the expenditure side, public safety is our top priority, with the police department budgeted at $6,276,178 and the fire department at $3,567,827. Notable expenditures also include:

The budget increase is primarily due to adding three new firefighters to support the upcoming Fire Station #2, which will open in 2025. Despite the expanded services, the Budget Team has done an exceptional job maintaining a balanced budget.

As we reflect on July's challenges and successes, we remain grateful for the strength and resilience of our community and our dedicated city staff. We are well-prepared to handle future crises and continue building a thriving Brenham.

July 2024

Happy Summer, Brenham! Here we are, already in July, seeing the best of our summer heat has arrived. This is one of our most fun months of the year. I encourage you to check the local listings and mark your calendars for some of these events. Brenham's highly anticipated summer concert series, Hot Nights, Cool Tunes , is set to return for its 20th anniversary celebration. This iconic event is a Brenham “tradition” and offers a lineup of musical performances and community festivities. It features four consecutive Saturdays of live entertainment, starting on July 6th and ending on July 27th. Each weekend showcases a different band, offering a diverse range of musical styles: Suede, The Pictures Band, Brown Sugar Band, and The Spicolis. All concerts are held on Saturday evenings at the Courthouse Square in Downtown Brenham and begin at 7:00 PM. This is free family-friendly fun and open to everyone.

Last Friday, Judge John Durrenberger, Carolyn Miller, Richard O'Malley, and I met with the owner of the post office building to discuss our need for a new facility. It was fortunate to finally have a contact person after years of trying to identify the owner of our current facility. Many individuals and several political figures have been unable to secure this information over the past 25 years or more. So, with some effort and a bit of luck, we managed to have this meeting and a walk-through of our local post office.

We expressed to the owner that the current facility and its location can no longer serve the citizens of Brenham and Washington County due to the significant growth over the past 60 years. The previous post office was located at the corner of Main and Market St., which is now the Brenham Heritage Museum. The current location, built in 1964, was built when the population of Brenham and Washington County was 8,000 and 19,000, respectively. Today, these numbers have grown to 19,000 and 39,000. The current facility is outdated and inadequate for our needs.

Unfortunately, working with the U.S. Postal Service (USPS) is a real challenge and one that will not be easily resolved. The USPS is very guarded about providing any information that would help secure a new facility. Even using the Freedom of Information Act has not been successful in obtaining the necessary information. A recent court case and appeal were denied, with the ruling stating, "providing any information was inconsistent with good business practices because it places us (United States Postal Service) at a disadvantage in our leasing activities to our potential detriment." As you can see from this statement, obtaining any information about leases or a potential new facility will be very difficult. However, this does not mean it is impossible. We have been given some additional contact information for individuals and political figures that will hopefully assist us in our quest for a new post office.

info@cityofbrenham.org

June 2024

Last week, the city council, along with the city manager, department heads, and staff, dedicated an entire day to reviewing Brenham's 5-year capital plan. This comprehensive review follows numerous meetings and discussions aimed at equipping each department with a clear understanding of the city's needs over the next half-decade. Our goal is to ensure that Brenham continues to deliver essential services to its citizens and do so effectively.

Our total city budget for 2024 stands at $23 million, with approximately $15 million allocated to personnel costs. This leaves roughly $8 million for operations, maintenance, and capital requests. Clearly, there's a shortfall in funding, necessitating careful prioritization to ensure essential services remain sustainable within these budgetary constraints.

Public safety, specifically Police and Fire departments, takes precedence. The City Council is steadfast in ensuring these departments receive adequate funding to safeguard our community against crime and fire hazards.

In the Fire Department, priority lies in replacing two fire trucks, Ladder I and Ladder II, for $3.5 million. Unfortunately, due to supply chain delays, it will take four years to procure these vehicles. Plans are underway for the construction of Fire Station #2 in 2025, estimated at $6 million.

One of our most important functions and responsibilities as mayor and council member is ensuring the city operates within its budget and provides the services you deserve as citizens. We're fortunate to have a seasoned city manager, Carolyn Miller, and dedicated city staff highly trained at managing budgetary concerns.

May 2024

Welcome to May! By the time you read this, the annual Maifest celebration will be taking place at Fireman's Park for 134 years, dating back to its beginning in 1881. The event has taken place each year except for several years during World War I and II. The Brenham Maifest is a culmination of its Board. Royalty families, supporters, and friends who work diligently and tirelessly each year to create a festival that highlights and celebrates the heritage of our community. Once again, because of being more involved this year (my granddaughter Caroline Kenjura is Junior Queen), I am amazed at the unbelievable amount of hours spent on this event to ensure the Brenham Maifest remains "The Oldest Festival in the State of Texas". Preparation for the festival begins in January and continues through the final day of the event.

The two coronations for the Senior and Junior Courts highlight the youth of our community. The entertainment by various bands continues at the festival site along with food booths, crafts, and carnival rides. If you are new to Brenham or have yet to experience Maifest, I encourage you to attend the festivities. Again, thanks to all the supporters and volunteers who keep this tradition moving forward – and maybe some of the young participants this year will be able to attend the 200th Maifest Celebration in the year 2090.

Another celebration during May, that is near and dear to all of us, is Mother’s Day. It is a day that is all about the woman who raised you and shaped who you are as a person. From the packed lunches with napkin notes to the bandages applied after falling off your bike, to being the first to cry at your graduation - your mom was there for it all. It's important to thank her or remember her for all the love and work she put in through the years to make you a better person. Thank you, Mom!

The 50-year anniversaries of the Brenham State Supported Living Center (May 10) and Memorial Oaks Chapel (May 22) mark significant milestones worth celebrating. It's wonderful to see these institutions serving the community for half a century.

Events like the Boys and Girls Club Gala and Fundraiser (May 16) provide vital support for youth programs, while high school graduation ceremonies signify a new chapter for many young adults in Brenham and Burton.

The DPS meal fundraiser supporting the victims of the DPS tragedy demonstrates the community's compassion and solidarity during difficult times. It is Wednesday, May 15 from 4:30 PM - 7:00 PM at Batter Box on FM 389. Tickets can be purchased from various businesses in town. Please help support this worthwhile cause.

Last, it is hard to believe this weekend marks one year since I was elected Mayor of this great community. The City of Brenham is blessed to have outstanding employees and administrators who genuinely care for this place we all call home. I, along with the City Council strive to do our very best to keep Brenham-Brenham.

February 2024

There has been considerable media coverage since the beginning of the year regarding " impact fees ," which will be presented to the city council in the coming weeks. Discussions on these fees were initially brought to the council in May 2023, and since then, several meetings with the public and developers have taken place to enhance understanding. A workshop and discussion on this topic were presented at our recent council meeting, followed by another meeting and a special presentation to developers and contractors for further insights and input.

The primary purpose of these fees is to shift some of the financial responsibility for new development from the city and its taxpayers to the developers. While this approach is common in nearby cities, Brenham is one of the last to implement such fees. As with any new initiative, there are pros and cons, and we welcome your opinions and input.

Recently, a meeting was held by TxDOT concerning the Hwy 290/36 interchange , where citizens voiced their concerns. Construction is set to begin in 2027, with completion expected in 2029-2030. Concerns have also been raised about the proposed raised median along S Day from Stone St to Hwy 290. A letter from my office to TxDOT has been sent expressing the concerns of businesses along this route, indicating that it would be very problematic for them and the public if this project is allowed to happen.

City Manager Position

On January 29th, the city council spent a substantial amount of time reviewing applications for the city manager position. We received a total of 17 applications that met the required qualifications.

I received a question regarding the maintenance responsibility for detention ponds that are in many areas of our city limits. As we know, some of these can become an eyesore with overgrown vegetation. The property developer or homeowners’ association, not the city, is responsible for maintenance. The newest detention pond near the Academy store will be maintained by the developer (Market Square Development).

Regarding sidewalk improvements on Park St, this project is funded by TxDOT, and no city funds are being utilized. The project will extend from the intersection of Blue Bell Rd. and Park St. (Burger King) along S. Austin and S. Day St. to the intersection of Hwy 290/36 (Jack in the Box). Completion for this is scheduled for the end of 2024.

Thank you for your questions, and again, I can be reached at info@cityofbrenham.org or receive mail at:

January 2024

Here's wishing everyone a Happy and Healthy New Year. I hope everyone had a Merry Christmas with family and friends and that Santa was good to those of you who were nice and not naughty. It's incredible how fast time goes by, especially this time of year. Personally, it seems like it was just yesterday that I was sworn in as mayor and here we are ready to start a new year.

The growth experienced over the past couple of years has been incredible and it has taken a team effort on behalf of all the city employees and staff to manage this growth. Permits in the residential and commercial sectors have begun to slow down, primarily because of the multiple interest hikes during the past year by the Feds. The good news is that in 2024 we should hopefully see several cuts in the prime interest rates. This “slowdown” is both good and bad in that it gives us a chance to catch up on the challenges to our infrastructure that have stressed all departments within the city, especially those dealing with water, electricity, and streets. Also, a little slowdown will help to maintain our identity in keeping Brenham-Brenham.

We understand the crucial role that growth plays in the development of any city, so as we anticipate ongoing expansion, this growth must occur in a manner that aligns with our available resources, avoiding undue financial strain on taxpayers. Over the past year, water has been a major focus, as a lifeblood of a community, leading to extensive planning and research to ensure a sustainable water supply for many years to come. Unfortunately, the estimated cost of the associated project stands at approximately $65 million. To meet this financial demand, there will be a need for incremental rate increases over a designated period for both commercial and residential water users. I will continue to give you updates as decisions are made with the City Council.

Another priority for 2024 is the continued planning, building, and staffing of Brenham's second fire station. This is in response to our rapid growth and is a necessity for the good of our community.

Next, as I’m sure you have heard, our City Manager, Carolyn Miller, has announced her retirement effective April 1, 2024. It will be difficult to replace Carolyn who has been with the city for 19 years and the last two and a half years as City Manager. It has been a true pleasure working with her and we all wish her the very best in her retirement. The process and recruitment of securing a new City Manager has begun. City Council decided not to contract with a search firm but to do an in-house search, led by Human Resource Director Susan Nienstedt and her staff. The proposed timeline is to begin conducting in-person interviews by the end of February and select a City Manager by the end of March 2024.

Last, but not least, I would like to thank everyone who has personally told me they enjoy reading this monthly “Mayor’s Minute”. I have enjoyed writing it even though sometimes it seems the monthly submission comes along rather fast. My goal and intention is for the article to be informative and discuss what might be on the citizens' minds. For 2024, I’d like to invite you to submit your questions for me and I’ll address them, each month, throughout the year. Questions may be submitted to info@cityofbrenham.org or mailed to:

In this edition of the Mayor’s Minute, I wish to shine a spotlight on several noteworthy matters that warrant our attention.

First and foremost, I extend my heartfelt congratulations to the myriad of organizations and individuals who played integral roles in the various Halloween festivities in our city last week. These events, thoughtfully designed with our youth in mind and emphasizing safety and fun, are a tremendous asset to our community. Following our recent council meeting, we held a retirement reception in honor of Assistant Fire Chief Brian Scheffer, whose remarkable 26 years of service to our community deserve our recognition and gratitude. In Brian’s speech, he expressed his appreciation to the City of Brenham and the fire department for entrusting him with this significant role. Brian eagerly anticipates his new role with Texas A&M TEEX and Region 7, which encompasses the Brenham area. Furthermore, Brian has graciously agreed to continue serving on a part-time basis, assisting with essential reporting and providing his leadership until an interim or permanent fire chief can be appointed. Thank you, Brian, for your service and leadership to our fire department over the years.

Thirdly, I wish to draw your attention to an upcoming public hearing scheduled for November 16, from 4:30 to 6:30 PM at the Blinn College Student Center. The purpose of this hearing is to provide information and gather feedback from our community regarding a proposal to enhance South Day Street. This TxDOT-led project seeks to raise the median and incorporate dedicated left-turn lanes along South Day Street from W. Stone Street to US 290. Representatives from TxDOT will be present to address any questions the public may have regarding this initiative. Should you have specific questions before the meeting, please feel free to reach out to Sydney Fox, TxDOT Bryan District, at 979-778-9231.

Fourthly, I want to emphasize the importance of election day, which falls on November 7. While there are no city or county elections at this time, there are 14 proposed amendments to the state constitution that warrant our attention and your invaluable right to vote so I encourage everyone to put this on your calendars.

Next, I’d like to take this time to express my deep gratitude to the brave men and women who have served in our nation’s armed forces. On November 11, let us not only remember the veterans of the past but also support those who continue to serve. Last but certainly not least, we must recognize the significance of the upcoming decision facing the Brenham Independent School District Board regarding the selection of the next Superintendent. This decision will undeniably stand as one of the most pivotal choices the Board will make in the coming years. The input from the public in recent weeks has underscored the necessity of appointing an individual with an unwavering commitment to Brenham, someone who will serve in this position for the long haul, rather than using it as a stepping stone. There is no facet more critical to our community than education. October 2023

This month’s topic is of the utmost importance - water. It is clear the City of Brenham is facing a critical need for water supply and treatment facility upgrades. As you may know, the City Council has approved a contract with Strand Associates to address the city’s water needs and improve the existing water treatment facility on South Austin Street.

The City has owned and operated water treatment facilities at the current location since 1894. The City moved to a surface water treatment system in 1972 with an 18-inch line to Lake Somerville. A 24-inch line was added in 1995 and the 18-inch line was abandoned. The last major plant expansion was in 1987 when treated water capacity was increased from 3.5 MGD (million gallons a day) to 6.984 MGD. Thus, the current water plant has served the community for over 35 years, and as with anything in service for that many years, it’s in need of improvements and replacements.

This has been a difficult decision for past city councils because of the costs associated with a project of this magnitude. But, the time has come to “bite the bullet,” as the saying goes. Whether we want it or not, growth happens. We have a responsibility to ourselves and future generations to supply the city with enough water and to ensure the quality of this water meets or exceeds all standards as specified by the State of Texas and our own high standards.

To accomplish this, we have had several proposals to secure more water for the city. After much discussion, the chosen solution is to drill deep water wells in strata that are at a depth of 500 – 1,000 ft. to secure a long-term water supply. The other choice was to construct a second line to Lake Somerville but the costs to lay the line and to construct a new lake intake station were deemed too expensive; therefore, the decision to proceed with the deep water wells was made. One concern with drilling within the city limits was that it would affect citizens with existing wells outside the city limits but because of the depth of the wells, this will not affect the existing wells of our county residents.

Of course, all of this comes with a price tag that is expensive and necessary. A city cannot run out of water! As a new mayor, the last thing I want is to raise water rates for residential and commercial customers, but the city has no other choice. Our utility department is looking at ways to help offset the proposed increases but with a projected expenditure of over $36 million.

We face many challenges when we talk about water but I am confident we have all the right people and components in place to be successful. The City’s water treatment plan is fortunate to have seven talented and dedicated personnel who are committed to ensuring a reliable and safe water supply for the community. Their hard work and expertise are vital to the success of the city’s water initiatives. We have a city council willing to make tough decisions to address the water challenges. And, the city, as a whole, benefits from an exceptional staff that is fully engaged and committed to finding solutions to many day-to-day challenges. This “all hands on deck” approach underscores the city’s determination to secure a bright future for Brenham.

Thank you for the opportunity to explain our water challenges and would like to personally invite you to attend our council meetings as we will be discussing this issue in the coming months.

September 2023

I’d like to personally take a minute to thank all of you for taking time out of your busy schedules to attend the Town Hall on August 10 to discuss the Brenham Family Park Small Area Plan. The meeting was very well attended and was interactive and informative. Your voice is integral in shaping so many things in our community and your engagement in this viable and sustainable plan is greatly appreciated. This project hasn’t come without its list of challenges. Yet, City staff has worked hard to work through things like land acquisitions and permitting with the end goal of marrying potential uses with Brenham's unique character and capturing its small-town allure while enhancing our entire community. That’s not an easy task!

This parkland was donated by Ed and Evelyn Kruse in December 2013 and development will likely begin in the summer of 2024. Our Small Area Plan, while it includes the land surrounding the park, firmly excludes any potential for commercial or residential development within the park itself. This commitment underscores our dedication to maintaining its essence as a passive family park.

The Mayor’s Minute

A New Dawn: Embracing Change as Your New Mayor

I am humbled and honored to address you today as the newly elected mayor of our wonderful community. As I step into this role, I bring with me a deep sense of responsibility and a strong commitment to serving each one of you.

Change is often met with mixed emotions. Some may feel apprehensive, while others embrace it with open arms. First and foremost, I want to express my gratitude to all the previous administrations that have worked tirelessly to lay the foundation for our city's success. Their dedication and efforts have brought us to this point, and I vow to build upon their achievements while addressing the challenges that lie ahead.

One of my top priorities is to promote transparency and foster an open dialogue with the community. I firmly believe that progress can only be achieved when leaders actively listen to the concerns and aspirations of their constituents. I will be accessible and approachable, encouraging your feedback and actively seeking your input on key decisions that affect Brenham. I want to emphasize the importance of community engagement and civic participation. Our city is only as strong as its residents, and it is through active involvement that we can shape the future we envision. I encourage every one of you to get involved, whether it's volunteering, joining boards and committees, or participating in local events. Together, we can build a stronger, more vibrant community that we can all be proud of. The Mayor’s Minute will be written once a month and available in The Banner Press and on the City of Brenham’s Facebook page. I will also be launching Mondays with Mayor Kenjura where you can submit questions and on the first Monday of each month, I’ll be on Facebook to answer them.

I am excited to embark on this journey. Change is not always easy, but with your support, we can overcome any obstacles that come our way. Let us embrace this new dawn and work together to create a city that thrives on our strong heritage and small-town feel, and where everyone has the opportunity to succeed and flourish.

Want to ask Mayor Kenjura a question? Use our online form at cityofbrenham.online/website-survey and be sure to check "To ask the Mayor a question".
